number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												This is probably the best asymmetric RTS/FPS hybrid of all time, but there really aren’t that many of them so that really isn’t huge deal. More importantly, this is probably one of the best games of all time as it contains a mixture of unique gameplay elements that no other games has. It definitely is my favourite game which actually sounds a bit strange to me when I think about it.I find that strange because I never really enjoyed FPS games a great deal. Prior to NS2 I played mostly strategy titles (RTS and turn based), and I believe what hooked me into this game was the gameplay elements of deep strategy, blended in with teamwork and individual skill. All these aspects of the game are so important that it is really not clear which one of them is more important in this game. Possible concerns: This game is niche title, with an active (albeit small) community where you really shouldn’t have any trouble finding a game. If you are worried that you “missed the boat” I don’t think you have anything to worry about if you are interested in this game. I don’t think it is likely the game will outright “die” as it fills a gameplay niche that is very difficult to get right like NS2 has. For the best experience find a server/community you like, help them seed a their server and you’ll have fun. The game isn’t particularly expensive and even goes down to 5$ at steam sales.Most people who have an issue with the game don’t really have huge issues with the game itself but with their perceptions of the community and health of the game (see discussions). However, despite these issues the game is still very much supported by the developers and has a dedicated community so their should be no reason why you shouldn’t give the game a shot if you are at all interested in the game. The servers/communities are fairly diverse and I suggest you look into all the different communities (make sure to also look in the arcade tab in the server browser) to find one that suits you before you make any judgements as a whole.Edit: Anyone claiming this game is full of hackers is full of it. I've ran into maybe 1 or 2 people I was fairly sure were hacking in my >2000 hours of NS2. NS2 is under VAC protection and hacking for this game is rare. Take anyone with <100 hours who claims they've seen a hacker without sufficent proof with a grain of salt. Honestly they likely ran into people who are just likely much better than them, and their egos couldn't take it. Gameplay: This is a RTS/FPS hybrid so it can be difficult to describe what the gameplay actually feels like in a short summary.On the field (where most of your time is spent):The game can be very fast paced, requiring good twitch reaction skills to be good in traditional combat situations. Thus, it might feel like the game is initially just like any other FPS where for the most part it seems like winning is about out-killing your opponents. However, the goal in the game is actually to economically starve  your opponents (via territory/map control) and to ultimately kill their last command structure. Everything else in the game emerges from that. This means there are other game elements unexpectedly sprinkled in, like stealth elements, tactical fake-outs, secret backdoor rushes, baiting, distractions, and sometimes killing yourself intentionally (to respawn at base or to kill a critical structure). Thus, having a keen strategic mind to spot and exploit opportunity, even if you aren’t a commander, is an asset in this game.Commanding:If you want to try commanding it cannot be understated how important the role is, but not in the way you might think. Commanding can be fast paced, like a game of starcraft, but feels different from a traditional RTS as you cannot directly control your core “units”. To win, team cooperation is the most important thing. Each core “unit” has a mind of their own and if you do anything to demoralize them by doing things they don’t understand or don’t commonly see when playing other games this can basically make your time commanding unbearable. To mitigate this, you need communication (to explain what you are trying if someone questions you), and need to show that you have an understanding how the game works (requires watching games/commanders or playing on the field a while).Concerns relating to the high skill ceiling of the game:There is a lot of talk about how hard the game is as relatively high skill veterans make up a large portion of the persistent player base. If you play past the rookie stage you will play against 1 or 2 these guys and I’d imagine it can feel like you can’t do anything against these guys. I’m probably almost one of them at this point, but I do remember a time when I wasn’t, and a key thing to remember is that this game is actually a strategy game and getting kills on your opponents doesn’t matter as much as you might think.For instance, when I know I can’t out-skill/kill the other team, I instead focus on thinking “what is the most productive thing I can do instead”. In NS2 you don’t need to kill the enemy team’s players to win, so worrying about your KDR is mostly not productive. As an alien, if you can’t win straight up fights realize that you don’t even need to always fight. Get past the enemy lines and hit unprotected resource nodes (you can crawl on walls silently and vents exist for a reason). For new players who find the combat difficult, just being aware of what is happening around the map (flashing red things) can be much more of an asset then being able to obtain a high KDR.You will get better at the game, in the meantime, try to compensate in other ways. There are some skill limit servers (e.g. Dungeon Gaming <1800 hive) that you could try to seed to minimize your exposure to high skilled players. Finally, I almost feel bad saying this because it is open to abuse, but in the worst case scenario if you don’t feel ready for non-rookie servers and your time is up - Make a family sharing account and play on that to get rookie status again if you need it. Remember, rookie servers are for people learning the game, please don’t abuse it. Overall, after you get the basics from a few rounds on rookie servers and the tutorials I strongly encourage learning the game in depth in non-rookie servers to learn the game faster.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Having played this game for so long and giving it another try, I remember well I stopped playing in the first place.  The two teams are not just asymmetrical, they are outright unbalanced.  So much so that a single, high tier player is all it takes to decide the game.  There is just no way to deal with how crazy some of their aiming capabilities are or ability to dodge as aliens.  This fact along makes the game a chore to play, add in the learning curve and the fact that UWE has never been good at balancing the gameplay.  The original NS had significant imbalance issues that took practically the entire development of that mod to finally iron out, by then it was desolate of an active, teeming player base.  Natural Selection 2 is a game with great setting, art style, and technical chops.  It is a shame the core gameplay can be so lopsided and difficult to work through.  Add in that the developers have for all intents and purposes abandoned the game to the community.  That is the death knell of a game, from here on out it is just running on the original steam from its release.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												My beef with this game is that it rewards only those who understand the glitches and overpowered techniques in this game. For example. Using a skork unit and trying to ambush a skilled marine will result in the marine hopping out of sight and into the air while doing a 360 turn midair, while reloading, then shooting you once with the shotgun and you are dead.Forget about the 10 minutes it took you to sneak up to this player. Attacking someone in the back will result in the human jumping in to the air and dodging all future melee attacks. It takes up to 4 melee attacks to kill a marine. this makes it so that you cannot sneak attack players and be rewarded for your stealth. The only time sneak attacks will work are when you attack a noob marine.This is why I quit the game because stealth is not rewarded and only those players who have been playing this for ages will win the fights because they know all the ridiculous glitches to come on top of a fight no matter what you do.I also think that late game, these massive units appear in the game where players control a mech or a giant dinosaur rhino, kind of ruin it completely. Things look really arcady and cheesy sometimes. Especially when all the marines hop around jumping higher in the air than the actual aliens.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												It's not perfect, just like any game, but this is one of, if not the, best game in my library. It's a multiplayer shooter/RTS hybrid, as in; if you're the commander, you have a top down view and can build structures, order troops, and more. Although the two teams, (alien and marine) are completely different, it is balanced better than any game in existence that offers aesymmetical gameplay. The marines are more like your standard shooter, but there's no aim down sights, like many of the best tactical shooters such as CS, but the aliens are the most fun, with their in-mouth view. With the aliens, you can evolve to different species, you start off as a skulk, then, (in order of cost) Gorge, the healer, the Lerk, A flying Creature, The Fade, with it's deadly claws and blink ability. Then there is the Onos, the tank. All these are brought with resources, which you get for capturing res towers and holding them. It's the best multiplayer game I've ever played.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												- 9 / 10 - NS2 is a fast-paced action FPS, heavily reliant on team-work, strategy & twitch reactions. It's a unique blend of FPS with real-time strategy elements. It pits two teams (Aliens VS Marines) against each-other in online matches. Graphics are very nice, performance is ok - the custom made engine (Spark) does seem to be quite CPU demanding, yet a comprehensive options menu allow for various tweaking. Gameplay is awesome, sound assets are okay.  It's good fun, competitive, but also newbie friendly. Has a great community that are steadily active (so you'll always be able to find a game). It's essentially a game about map / resource control, upgrading / evolution tech research & using various weapons / skills & abilities - it's pretty sweet.As a huge fan of both the original HL1 mod & the indie dev team, I must admit I wasn't too impressed with the initial release due to bugs, performance issues, lack of content & balancing issues - yet true to their word UWE rolled out (& continue to do so) patches / updates & free content, fully addressing my intial concerns. I fully respect UWE approch to the development process where they where open to community suggestions & really made an effort to involve players with the process even from pre-order. If not even pioneering the technique of early-access / beta release with ongoing development.This is a must play for any action FPS fan!

												I have never spent so much time on any other game.  It's unique, and it requires learning and teamwork.  It has it's problems, it had many more in the past but it's come a huge way performance wise.  The community b***** oft about this being a broken game, but in it's current state it suffers less plaguing issues than many good multiplayer titles period.  I very highly recommend it if you can take the time to look up things on commanding, listen to good players and just learn.  Check out ensl.org.  That's where the majority of the community is now, and you can sign up for pugs whoever you are and whatever your skill level is.  More balanced games.http://steamcommunity.com/id/savant99/recommended/4920This review is also well worded with strong points for the flip side.  I'm not even a remotely competitive level of player for anything, I just really got into this game none the less.  Read and consider for yourself.  Community is fairly small right now, more people need to pick up and love this very deserving game.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Natural Selection 2 (NS2) Is a First person shooter real time strategy  (FPSRTS) game (multiplayer only) It is a game designed for the more hardcore gamers and the learning curve of this game is steep,  however, once you get to know the game and how the mechanics work it is one of the most addictive games around. It is updated reguarly There are tutorials in this game that will give you some of the basics but it is a lot to take in and it will take about 20-30 hours of playtime to get the basics in. Not to worry though, there are plenty of rookie's like yourself out there and there are server designed to help out new players. The game requires an up to date computer with a high-end graphics card to play the game in all it's detail, but even with my GTX660 while playable in the highest settings I prefer to set it on low to gain this extra FPS for aiming. If you're a bit of a hardcore gamer this game can be your next addictive game for a long time, but if you're a casual players and don't have much time to invest, this won't be the game for you. Pro's - Great gameplay combo- Good Graphics- Great community- Price, 2,29 when 90% offCons- Steep learning curve- Requires a fast PC with high end Graphics card

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												OK, So i am editing this after a long hiatus from the game. I have played this game more than most other people.I tried to introduce some new players to the game recently, and i don't believe either were sold on the game, with the main complaints being : "its hard to aim the guns cause the targets move so fast and are so small." and "its hard to understand the strategy in the game, cause its so complicated."One experience which really led me to the conclusion that the strategy is hard to grasp, is the frequency with which i was the only one on my team who realised we had just lost, or won a game.My opinion is that they released this game too early, at a time where to get decent FPS during combat a PC of ridiculous spec was required, most people had a bad time playing the game at this point.These days, it is well optimised and running on machines that didn't exist when it was released, it is an incredibly smooth play, i get a buttery smooth 144fps.Because this game was released in an unfinished state, MAJOR changes were made to the game after its release, which completely destroyed any chance the game had. The addition of gorge tunnels was particularly irritating to me personally (as it made the teams less diverse).There were other major changes, i have to admit i wasn't a fan of this chopping and changing, because i have put so much time and energy into maximising the efficiency of my strategy, only to have to start over from scratch on the next update.This, was what eventually led me to leave the game, near the introduction of gorge tunnels.After a couple of years break from the game, i have come back. The game is well optimised now, the combat is snappy and enjoyable, the strategy hasn't been messed with. I could play this game, if there were enough other people playing it! This is a VERY GOOD GAME, I don't think there is a skill ceiling for the strategy and combat, if there is, i haven't reached it !This game trains your aim, hearing, and combat sense. After playing in this game, go and play counterstrike and see how much easier the aiming seems.If you like games where you have to have incredible aim, and a deep understanding of strategy, this game is for you! Oh, and also get a microphone, or don't buy the game :)

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												Natural Selection 2 is a amazing concept and makes for amazing game play especially if you have friends. A lot of people complain about the community being “Too Veteran” or “God-Like” and that makes it hard for new players. I say that this is true, but they can't help it if they have played the game for so long. If you are completely new, I recommend Bot matches against the computer even if others don't recommend itBot matches are not designed to be challenging for veterans, but if you are new they are very helpful. They allow you to explore the games systems and try-out everything. Things that may be too expensive for you to risk buying in a real match in fear of screwing up. The hardest difficulty Bot matches actually are challenging for new players so don't listen to people who say “Playing Bot matches will ruin your skills forever” or stupid comments like that because they are not true.Once you are ready (which can take a load of bot matches to reach), try a easy multilayer match and see how you go. Even if you lose you can learn from the experience.Don't fall into the trap of buying the game, getting really exited, immediately joining a multiplayer match, get totally destroyed by other players and then stop playing the game because its “too hard”. If you are desperate for some multilayer action you can try to create a server (if you know how ;_;) or join a empty server and invite your friends. Really great game! Just don't be surprised about the difficulty level. It is a hard game!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												This is my very first review on Steam and, unfortunately, I will not recommend to buy this game. I purchased the game some time ago but I had problems with my NVidia + Linux combo until a few days ago when I updated my drivers. The first experience of going through a training is pretty OK-ish, but when it comes to the multiplayer, the game can be thrown away.Constant timeout errors prevented me from connecting to ANY of the game servers. I have NEVER had any problems with OTHER online games. This game requires a VERY SPECIAL treatment for the multiplayer to work. I am not kidding here, the official support forum actually has quite a lot of posts on how to tune/configure your routers to be able to play this game. Have you ever seen anything like that? You need to configure your router to be abler to play a game (i.e., to workaround problems of poor software design and implementation of the multiplayer components of the game).Considering that the multiplayer is the main backbone and the main problem of this game, I can say - this game is unplayable. Considering the size of the NS2 dev team (9 ppl), the amount of patches (200+) they delivered on Steam and the fact that the problem is still (after several years) not resolved, I can say - the problem will not be resolved (i.e., it will require resources that the dev team does not have since they already in the maintenance mode and money are not coming anymore).To summarize: the game is broken, dead and abandoned. Do not buy it.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												NS2 is a great game for what it is, but be prepared to; A: have a decent computer to play it on (I recommend a minimum of a 3.6GHz processor, 6gb RAM, and a GeForce 780 2gb or newer; B:  be prepared to spend a fair amount of time overcoming the learning curve.  You will need to practice practice practice if you want to get good, even just playing it 5 hours a week would likely only leave you "okay" for a long while.  The game rewards accuracy, twitch reaction speed, strategic playstyles, and teamwork.  With the exception of the twitch reaction speed (I have a fine motor deficit that makes twitch speed hard for me) , I find all of these things to be good things.  You will find the two team types to be fairly well balanced, though at lower skill levels the Aliens may seem a tad more powerful (even then it is by very little, I think I averaged 58/42 Alien/Human when I was learning the ropes), but the humans tend to take a few more games in the higher skill levels (with the midground being fairly well 50/50).  The humans get enough cool weapons and gadgets to let you find a playstyle that fits you (though make sure your Commander knows any specific things you want researched or you may not get your prefered loadout), and the Aliens all play differently from each other with their own set of morphs that serve as battlefield upgrades.The only reasons I would tell someone not to buy this game is if they don't have a beefy enough system to run it properly, the person doesn't like sticking with the team and wants to run off to fight solo (this will almost always end in a quick death for said player), or you just won't be playing regularly enough to grow in skill (you need to have at least 2 hours every week while you are playing, in my opinion, to ensure that you are not stuck being a target to more skilled players all the time).  Other than that, if you like cooporative squad tactical shooters, this is probably going to be right up your alley.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Great on paper but a buggy, glitchy, obtuse and convoluted game overall. What's the point of a shooter if the shooting ain't fun and exciting to begin with? There's barely any satisfactory gun feedback. The enemy animations are risible and the way they attack/charge at you from like 5 meters away it's just silly. NS2 features one of the most unnecessarily intricate level designs I've seen in my entire gaming life for these type of shooters, there's no flow to them, it's a chore to travel back and forth between rooms, it's a labyrinthic mess. The engine, as far as I know, it's not based on UE3 so 'featuring' texture pop-in -that takes even minutes to load- it's even more bizarre. The performance is terrible overall, very unoptimized and it doesn't look that hot to begin with, the pictures are really misleading. Add to that the extremely long, annoying load times -even for a training match with bots-.A shame really, it looked like it could have improved on Aliens vs Predator and delivered what Colonial Marines didn't on the MP aspect. Good thing I got it on a Humble Bundle for cheap. But don't listen to Bixby Snyder, don't buy this even for a dollar!

number of helpful: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Counter-Strike meets Starcraft. Marines have ranged weapons, explosives and siege artillery. Aliens have teeth, claws, speed and excessive maneuverability, and range in size from cat to rhinoceros. Marines structures require power to function.Alien structures build on infestation and slowly die when it subsides.Each team has a commander that manages sturctures and upgrades via a top-down view.Natural Selection is the single most thrilling, most competitive first person shooter I have ever played since the release of its Half-Life 1 mod in the mid 2000s. Sure, Battlefield delivers large-scale modern warfare in life-like graphics and SFX, but it fails nonetheless (like any other FPS I could think of) to implement half incredible teamplay potential that Natural Selection does! Basically, you have a team of marines on one side of the map and an alien Hive on the other. The alien Hive is where the eggs spawn, and the aliens will aim to optimally build three or more Hives to unlock all their upgrades and reach full strength. It's up to the marines to eliminate the aliens before the situation spins out of control. The game goes by controlling the map's resource nodes (scattered evenly between the 8-12 rooms that make up each map) in order to unlock higher weapons/lifeforms and upgrades faster, and ultimately kill all the enemy's command structures (the alien Hive or marine Command Center). And what makes it so full of heat is how quickly a single move could change the tide of battle! Both teams have structures made for quick commuting: teleporters for marines and underground tunnels for aliens. If used correctly, your entire team could be in the enemy base in less than 20 seconds. Normally, the marines have to set up and DEFEND teleporters at Hive entrance chokepoints to suffocate the aliens by constantly teleporting in and damaging the Hive while preventing the aliens from scattering all over the map. The aliens on the other hand are better at sneak attacks; eliminating lonely marine resource nodes and setting up "sneaky tunnels."When the aliens successfully lay a tunnel to the marine base undetected, their whole team could be in the marine base in less than 15 seconds! And then it's up to the marine commander to trigger the Distress Beacon to teleport all marines back in time or else the base would be overrun. But even when the base is defended successfully, the aliens will usually utilize this mass relocation of the marines to eliminate their structures somewhere else on the map!The aliens also have the choice whether to destroy the marine structures in each room or to aim for the power node, which, once broken, conceals the room in pitch black darkness and disables all marine structures in it. Up until the red emergency lights come online, the only thing any rines in the room can see is whatever crosses the thin strip of flashlight that they have.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 15
												Just a few points that keeps me from coming back to the game after playing a lot of hours during the early development and launch when the game felt like a different exprence. Things seemed pretty good at first with matches feeling like a proper match between two groups trying to fight it out for supremacy. This lead to some crazy moments with some teams turtling to draw out the matches, others doing blind rushes to reset another teams upgrades, and other such moments. Over time those moments faded away as the game was pushed more towards the esports scene. During that time you could feel the change in the game, but everything stayed pretty much the same with some games being a quick match with one team dominating while others were as I descirbed before. Now I come back to the game after a long pause due to a friend to find that the community is toxic and the matches have been sped up to crazy speeds. I've jumped in and out of a few matches because even back when they started making huge overhalls you would end up with some teams that just didn't mesh well with one another. All I could ever find is one team always dominating another. On top of that is the toxic community that I mentioned a few sentences back. You can look in the community and see the tip of what I mean with comments like this game not being friendly to noobs or just flat out saying that the vets in the game are aggressive to anyone new. I played a game just the other day with four vets that refused to join a team because of this new mechanic called hive score. I don't even know the details of it. The most that I get from the mechanic is that it is some way to try and rate a player much like the old gear scores that you would see in MMOs. You can take this whole review as me just missing the old days back when there were a larger number of people to play with. It might have been a situation that with that larger number you had a higher chance of ending up with people that wanted to play just to have fun in the game. Now, it's turned into just another arena shooter that attaches a skinner box to give you a reason to play or in some cases as the match from before to not play a match. The game had it's time for new players before becoming what it is now.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												This game is a fantastic blend of RTS and FPS with the players choice dictating how they play. The Alien and Marine teams aren't exactly equal as the Marines have more ranged weapons and the Aliens have melee and close ranged attacks along with two or three ranged attacks and also have a greater utilization of the map as they can climb walls and enter vents. The commander plays it like an RTS yet each unit is an actual player. It's a fantastic game that requires some team play and lets you really get invested in each match. You will soon find the team and weapons that suit you and you'll fit comfortabley right into the game. If you ever played Tremulous or Gloom, which are amazing mods based off the same concept as they were the first to try this split team dynamic, then you will certainly enjoy this updated version of the classic style of FPS.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Natural Selection 2 is a multiplayer based game where 2 teams (Aliens and Marines) must battle it out to best your opponent by evolving the way you play, literally evolving... that’s an actual mechanic... but not like the, it takes millions of years to grow feet because, well you already have them. How does the multiplayer, well, play?It is actually quite a nice blend of strategy and first person carnage, each team has a commander, it’s up to the commander to distribute orders for both buildings and troops and also upgrade their soldiers to be the best they can be in a battle. Now this does take a bit of skill, a dash of map knowledge and a whole heaping of luck, to get a good team of experienced players that is. Sounds a bit intimidating doesn't it, stop being such a baby, there’s a very instructive tutorial you can play through before you jump into the action for both Alien and Marine commanders and also their infantry counterparts.Speaking of the infantry, they're pretty fun to play as also, at first the gameplay will feel a bit hectic, the map is bigger than your usual CoD map and there are a lot of different angles and vents the Alien horde can come at you from but once you gain a bit of map knowledge and you learn the ropes a little you'll be murdering hundreds and hundreds of Aliens that for all we know might just be expressing their need for a cuddle or a wingman to go to the club with... I dunno.The alien infantry isn't that bad either, with a wide variety of Aliens to choose from you'll be spoiled for choice when it comes to evolving you little alien demon. You can either stay as the stock Skulk, a vicious and acrobatic killer with a deadly bite attack and low damage ranged assault that can mark your enemies for your teammates. Or maybe the supportive Gorge who acts as the team medic and can also build great walls of erm... unknown body fluids to block pathways to objectives or to shoehorn your enemy into an ambush... Tactics!Whatever you choose to play you can have a ruddy good time blasting holes in aliens using a variety of weapons and gadgets such as jetpacks and mech suits with big ol' guns on them or on the flips side you could turn into a flying alien or that invisible one or even better the massive rhino/triceratops that makes me cry on the inside. To sum it up, Aliens, Space soldiers, Big guns, Big aliens, decent controls, great gameplay, small learning curve as long as you put the time in and most of all overall fun, fun, fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Natural Selection 2 is quite a good multiplayer shooter. It mixes elements of FPS along with RTS. The commander is in control of building and supplying the team with health packs, upgrades, and objectives, while the rest of your team makes it all come together. Its quite the thing to behold being the commander and barking orders to your team and watching them all fall in line, leading to victory. Communication is key, as well as skill from your team players. Playing the marines is quite fun, but the aliens is where the game gets really interesting. Fighting as them, or against them is where the game really shines. As a marine, you must always watch your back and listen carefully, for the aliens have the advantage of being able to hide in vents, climb on walls and ceilings, and hide pretty much wherever they can fit. Some of the more deadly evolutions of the aliens can be a pain to deal with. Seeing the infestation spead along the space station is pretty awesome. This game is something you truly must experience. The only thing i can say negative about this game is not enough people play it, which can change depending on how many of you listen to this review and buy this masterpiece.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2013
												Natural Selection 2 is everything that makes a shooter great. Never before have I seen an asymmetric shooter that has so much love to detail and balance. It has good variety in weapons and "enemies" while making sure there is no such thing as useless equipment. Everything has a use and is viable, be it the starting rifle, the side pistol or the first alien life form. This game promotes and, indeed, needs team play and communication. An absolute fantastic online experience best enjoyed in 7v7 or 8v8 matches so to not lose the tactical feel as well as the importance of every individual involved.However, it is important to say that this game has an incredibly steep learning curve and will take several hours to even get your head around. Especially the role of the commander should not be taken before completely understandly the flow and priorities of matches as well as tactics. I myself have not filled the com station until 40 hours into the game for it is the most stressful and important position in every match. The community is very much aware of this learn curve and is, in general, very eager to explain the many questions beginners might have. And don't shy away from learning the alien side! It is an asymmetric shooter, after all.I can not recommend this game more appart from the dwindling player base as this game continues to age. It is definately my favorite shooter of all times and I really hope this game will see a continuation even though I would be just as happy with just a revival of the once large player base. Giving it a 10 would not suffice. This game has heavily influenced what I expect of online shooters to come.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Never played the original NS1, but one day, i've decided to just buy NS2. Don't know what made me buy it, i just sort of felt the need to do it. And man i'm glad i did it. There is so much stuff going on in this game it's just not possible to write it down in a reasonably short review.It's a blend of FPS and strategy game with great emphasis on team work. Because on your own, you're are a dead man/dead alien. Granted, hours and hours of training will give you a huge edge over new players, but doing it as a team helps even more.There are so many upgrades, different weapons, vehicles, tactics, methods of attacking, methods of coordinating attacks, exploiting environment and different paths, abilities. It's just insane and awesome!One thing that i recommend is that you get yourself a decent headphones with mic. Because the only way to play this game is to hear the team and communicate in real-time. Typing stuff is just too time consuming and clumsy. Keeping team up to date with combat status can often be a matter of win or lose. And don't even think of commanding without a headset. You just need it to do the job right.There is one special thing about this game, while it was made by indie developer, the game apart from occasional balance issues feels like a proper high profile AAA multiplayer game. It just all feels really professional, well executed and polished.Did i mention the graphics look absolutely amazing? It's incredible what kind of graphics engine they developed themselves for this game. I wish they'd sell it to other developers, because the worlds, models, effects and the lighting and shading itself is sometimes so realistic you could almost mistaken it for a photo. I'm not kidding!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Natural Selection 2 is a very fun and highly addictive FPS/RTS, that is practically a combination of Counterstrike and Command & Conquer. There are two teams, the Kharaa and the Marines, who each have a single leading player known as the Commander. The Commander's purpose is to construct and support the team's advance toward the enemy through upgrade researches and structures. The Commander can also "call-the-shots" by coming up with strategies for the team, depending on how well they communicate. The other players on the team are the combatants. They are the ones carrying the weapons, making good use of their commander's upgrades and helping to construct structures their commander has placed down. Surprisingly, Natural Selection 2 requires quite a large amount of effort from players in order to effectively defeat the enemy. From my experience, it is near impossible to make every bullet count, or to land every bite into the enemy, despite how effective one would be in a different game, such as Counterstrike. In contrast, the players in NS2 are moving around quickly and constantly in all possible directions, making certain situations very confusing. Nevertheless, practice makes perfect, and the goal of the game is to have fun, not to become the best player the game has. Natural Selection 2 is a great choice for anyone who enjoys alien versus soldier strategy games.

												I must say; this game is my favourite game of all time.It combines awesome asymmetrical co-op FPS gameplay with team-based RTS elements.Pro's:Balanced asymmetrical gameplay,Awesome RTS "Commander Mode" (Unique for both alien and marine),Constantly updated with new weapons, maps, etc.Cool sci-fi enviroments and weapons,Well made unique "Alien Traits" and Marine upgrades for each team, such as: Stealth, speed and power as alien, and armor and damage upgrades for Marines,Mod support,Few to no bugs,Well modeled characters,Unique game engine (Spark),Special structures for each team:Aliens have transportation tunnels (Gorge tunnels), offensive structures (Whips), etc. While Marines get; Teleporters, Sentry guns, etc.Good community with nice players, who welcome new players and are helpful to others.Con's:At the moment I can't seem to find anything wrong with it, so for me; i guess its kind of a perfect game.All in all a great game, which I love to death, no doubt for me; that i would rate this game:10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Damn solid  multiplayer game. Although the learning curve is pretty tremendous  for what seems to be a simple AVP concept, the reality is that Natural Selection 2 involves requiring strategy that most games do not. Each of the two teams of Aliens and Marines have one commander, a person who assumes a top view of the map and can order his soldiers to go to a certian location, complete an objective, upgrade their armor and weaponry, and build structures to fortify the main base and make their team more powerful. I have found that the community for NS2 is generally helpful to rookies, and most (not all) will give tips and advise to new players struggling with the heavy expectations for a team in the matches that can last upwards of half an hour. Occasionally you witness the gruff veteran who lacks patience for the new recruits, but you can pick up on the game mechanics fairly quickly before they nag at you consistently. The gameplay is solid and balanced, playing as either team is fun and enjoyable. Playing as the vulnerable aliens as you stalk your prey can be exhilierating, but hunting the agile opponets with a pulse rifle can be equally enjoyable. The best game involves high levels of cooperation for all, but when you win, it feels great to have contributed to a team and I think I can say the level of comradery felt between two people is greatest when you squinting in the dimly light power room trying to reconstruct power to get the lights on as knee-high aliens shoot acidic goo at your feet. Fantastic game at any price, and it is gaurenteed to last you quite a while.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												On one hand Natural Selection 2 is a fast-paced tactical shooter that relies heavily on teamwork and communication. On the other hand it's an intense asymmetrical real-time strategy game where being able to micromanage your units is just the beginning. These lead to intense gameplay scenarios where every player has a drastic impact on the outcome of the game. Natural Selection 2 represents a unique genre and does so extremely well. You have to try this!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2012
												A great Teamoriented Multiplayer-only RTS/FPS-hybrid with asymmetrical teams. A game where teamwork is a must to win and a mic more or less mandatory. I have had a blast in this game even though I have primarly played with random people. Everyone I have encountered so far is polite and taking the games serious. The game is kind of hard to explain but you could say it is like a FPS-version of StarCraft, where you can play as the commander or the footsoldier. The best way to understand the game is to check out a couple of video reviews. But I strongly recommend this game!Shameless update: Because of the Steam Awards I have nominated this game in to my category "The most underappreciated Multiplayer Game" because...well it is. I am still having fun with this game 4 years after release even though I only play it every fortnight. And it's better than ever.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Realy fun game, once you get the hang of it.A match can last from 2 minutes (poor balanced teams) to ~45 minutes (good balanced teams), but stands on an avarage of ~30 minutes per match. Before joining a NS2 match everyone should know that this is no deathmatch or tdm. This game mode is a combination of tactical and strategical gameplay.The key for victory in this game is communication between the team, even if you are a bad shoot.Beeing aware and knowing were and when to go can make the difference between win/loss and kill/death ratio.For my part I enjoy the alien lifeforms most, which rather rely on speed, stealth and clever gameplay with different playstyle.But the Marines do not stand behind with nice gadgets, like jetpacks, flamethrowers or exosuits with miniguns or railguns.But there are some things to learn before anyone can think of having a nice K/D ratio, so I recommend watching some basic tutorials.Even more I recommend using the ingame voice chat to ask questions if you are having difficulty in understandig the game or don't know what to do.The differention of rookie servers(marked green) and experienced servers(marked white) is a nice feature, and asking for help understanding the game is never wrong.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												NS2 is a PVP shooter unlike anything you have seen.It doesn't need recoil and spread to make shooting an enjoyable challenge as marine.As Alien you can dodge bullets like neo or stealthily surprise attack an unsuspecting marine from aboveboth sides are a real test of your reflexes and mindplayand if you just want to manage everything you can play Commander, place buildings, unlock weapons and skills: you control how your team should play.Aliens and Marines have dozends of skills and classes that change the way you play dramaticallybecome a swift winged beast or a rhino like killng machine, grab a jetpack and shotgun and never miss a shot in the heat of battle or control a mech walker with huge guns and armor. or just support your team with heals, repairs, constructing or building smaller support structures without needing to command.There are many ways to individualise your playstyleThe game is to this day being patched and balanced by people from the Community, so it is a very bug free and fair experience (if your teams have comparable gameplay experience of course).if you are not sure if the game is for you, you should mark it for later, it has been on -75% sale quite often so far. and cheap keys from sales are being sold on other sites as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Never played the original NS1, but one day, i've decided to just buy NS2. Don't know what made me buy it, i just sort of felt the need to do it. And man i'm glad i did it. There is so much stuff going on in this game it's just not possible to write it down in a reasonably short review.It's a blend of FPS and strategy game with great emphasis on team work. Because on your own, you're are a dead man/dead alien. Granted, hours and hours of training will give you a huge edge over new players, but doing it as a team helps even more.There are so many upgrades, different weapons, vehicles, tactics, methods of attacking, methods of coordinating attacks, exploiting environment and different paths, abilities. It's just insane and awesome!One thing that i recommend is that you get yourself a decent headphones with mic. Because the only way to play this game is to hear the team and communicate in real-time. Typing stuff is just too time consuming and clumsy. Keeping team up to date with combat status can often be a matter of win or lose. And don't even think of commanding without a headset. You just need it to do the job right.There is one special thing about this game, while it was made by indie developer, the game apart from occasional balance issues feels like a proper high profile AAA multiplayer game. It just all feels really professional, well executed and polished.Did i mention the graphics look absolutely amazing? It's incredible what kind of graphics engine they developed themselves for this game. I wish they'd sell it to other developers, because the worlds, models, effects and the lighting and shading itself is sometimes so realistic you could almost mistaken it for a photo. I'm not kidding!

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game is a true competitive FPS. Natural Selection 2 is an extremely underated game. It combines FPS action with RTS elements to make one of the most unique games you'll ever play.  I've sunk in nearly 800 hours so far and I can honestly say every round I have played has been different. Rookies tend to get discouraged at first because of the steep learning curve, but stick with it for a couple of hours and you will NEVER want to play anything remotely similiar to CoD or BF. I could sit here and go on and on about how great this game is and how it deserves much more attention. Instead I will throw a couple of negative things out there to be fair.The optimization is pretty bad. You don't need a super computer to run it or anything. Personally, I play on a three year old laptop. i7 2.3 Ghz8 Gb Ram660M GTXI can still normally run games on at least medium settings, but not Natural Selection 2. Even on mostly low settings, I only average 35 FPS. Another problem seems to be hit registration. There have been many times where I've shot lifeforms point blank (and see alien blood) yet I ended up doing zero damage. Other times, I'm an alien WELL around a corner and I'm still taking bullet damage.Those are my only two complaints. Do they keep me from playing? Obviously not. Is it gamebreaking? No. Should you get this game? No question.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												While the community was never titanic in it's size, it remains one of the best games I've ever played.I would recommend if you're reading this and its still the year 2016/first half of 2017 AND you're considering the game: Buy it now. By my estimation half way through 2017 the game's population will reach a level where it will no longer be possible to get a full game server in a local region thus depriving you of the amazing gameplay.Past June 2017 I would check how many people are playing if its sub 50 I would pass on the game unless its like 2$.The sad reality is that this game is dieing in terms of it's population, and it is entirely a multiplayer game. However that does not mean you wont get a good bit of fun out of the game, and its one of those games I'll always reinstall every few months to get a few rounds in.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Not your ordinary FPS shooter.  Team based objective game with a marines vs. aliens shooter theme to it.  Both marines and aliens has a commander who plays in a "starcraft style RTS" mode that builds, upgrades structures, and "micros" buffs/debuffs to your enemy and teammates.  Every one else plays as a marine or exosuit (mechs) versus different evolution of aliens ranging in support roles to assassin roles.  The game has been updated monthly and shows some response to the community.  Overall, if the support is consistent by "UWE" (Unknown Worlds), then the game will surely have a good lifespan for you.  There are a few modded servers that keep the game fresh and a unique game in every game you play.  Some of the negative aspects of the game though are the consistent team stacking, pro players coming into servers just to make the game depressing by steamrolling everyone, and lack of maps.  Pros: Unique style of gameplay, different forms of aliens to experience, coordinated team gameplay, and non mirrored matchup.Cons: One or two sharpshooters on the same team can ruin the game, well played fade or lerk lifeform can carry the entire alien team, balance issues, lack of maps, small community, heavy rookie learning curve.

												yes, yes i do.  like any community, especially a smaller one like this, there are going to be toxic players (and they are infamous) that give the community a bad rap.  and there are many players that are a little too good for the average pub  match, but because the number of servers with active games is so low, it's their only opportunity, and that tends to frustrate newer players that haven't grasped the difficult learning curve, especially on the alien side. but this community is largely a group of dedicated and passionate players that are a joy to play this game with. and yes, we suffer thru lopsided matches (oh it was so stacked that round!), because when you get a really good match and a well-played round, it is so totally awesome that you will suffer thru the drudge yet again in pursuit of that next great round high.  i have played far too much of this game, and i will play far too much more... nuff said

content:
Posted: November 3, 2012
												An team based FPS (and an RTS of sorts for your commander) where you fight over terriotry and resources. The game sports one team of human marines who rely heavily on their technoloy and weapons, and another team made of a gaggle of aliens each with their own strenghts and weaknesses and the ability to mutate which can drastically change gameplay. The game has quite the steep learning curve however there are tutorial and the ocmmunity can be very helpful. it stands to mention that the team behind this game has been releasing DLC free of charge and thats something that should be commended.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												This is an amazing  game in every way. If you're willing to invest some time and patience into learning and mastering this unique playstyle and all the different aspects of it, you'll be blown away by the incredible gameplay and fun that's waiting to be had with NS2.The graphics and art are beautiful, sure there are some better looking games out there (not that many) but everything in this game was crafted with attention to detail and immersion. The environments feel "lived in" and tell a story. The dynamic lights and assets (such as infestation) will allow you to visually see and feel the progression of a match. You will get fully immersed and invested into each match.Even the best looking games out there do not tell a story with their graphics the way NS2 does. This puts it in a league of its own.See for yourself:http://imgur.com/a/ZP9QV(those screenshots aren't even on the highest settings)The gameplay is demanding and intimidating for newcomers. You might feel disinterested or disconnected from the game at first, simply because you can't contribute much to the experience. This is something you just have to deal with for a few hours. Find good servers with friendly people, ask for advice and listen carefully, let them know you're new and eager to learn.Once you're over that initial hump, you will find yourself in a world with seemingly endless possibilities and strategies. I suggest you make some friends, play with the people you feel comfortable with, join servers and teams with them. A lot of the experience and the fun comes down to working as a team.Hardware requirements:I see a lot of complaints about endless loading times and poor framerates. Alright, this is not THE best engine ever made. But it is FAR from being bad. Let's keep in mind this is an indie game, made by a few people with no budget. Considering that, I think the engine deserves nothing but praise.Yes the loading times are somewhat long and even high end systems can be pushed to their limits, but there are good reasons for that. This is an insanely complex game, to be honest it's more like 2 games wrapped in one!The maps are huge and detailed. All those complex mechanics mentioned above need to be processed in real time. You simply cannot compare the performance to other FPS games, its a whole different beast. Thus the high system load is more than justified.Furthermore, 90% of those complaints are highly exaggerated, these people are either used to cheap CoD like console ports or have hardware that should sit in a history museum.Final words:NS2 comes down to what YOU do with it. It's a lot like giving you the keys to the Lamborghini. You can go and crash it, or learn how to drive it and unleash its full potential.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												A very well put together RTS/FPS Hybrid in a sci-fi setting with 3D-printed people, railguns and one hell of a bacterial infection. The game features asymmetrical combat between the more traditional marines who play as you would expect with typical shooter fare such as LMGs (the defauilt gun), shotguns and grenades. Reliant upon squad tactics and logistical support the marines may be more familiar, but require solid aim and awareness.The alien infestation are worlds apart, with a mix of disposable skulks, dog like aliens very similar in play to runner aliens from the early AvP games; through to Fades and Onoses, much more specialised lifeforms that are important to keep alive. The aliens are build around hit an run tactics and guerilla warfare; breaking supply and picking off isolated pockets to keep the marines on the defensive.The RTS aspect is really what makes the game special, there is macro and micro required. Commanders (limited to one lucky person per side) placing Resource Towers to allow marines to get new weapons and upgrades and aliens to evolve, and also being able to provide more direct help to his footsoldiers by dropping medpacks, ammo and scans.The game is very slick without being dumbed down, and is based on team work and strong tactics without being clunky. The game looks beautiful, but that has not been at the expense of gameplay.The one thing I cannot account for is the community, whilst I have had mostly positive experiences the game relies upon teamwork; thus, people not working as part of the team or following the commander's suggestions will be dead weight, something that will get on everybody's nerves. Rokkies are flagged up, and the developers have tried to encourage a forgiving environment, but trust me when I say there is one golden rule...Do as you are asked: you will have a lot more fun that way.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Natural Selection 2 offers a promising combination of strategy and first-person shooting, but disappointing execution holds it back. It is unquestionably a unique title, but its bar to entry is incredibly high for the average FPS player. For the hardcore strategist, it has its appeal, but its complexity severely limits the enjoyment in matches that aren’t significantly populated by experts at the game.Still, I am sure Natural Selection 2 will gather a group of devoted fans. After all it’s a surprisingly original game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												I don't normally play First Person Shooters, but this is an exception! Natural Selection two is a First Person Shooter/Real Time Strategy game. There are two sides: Aliens and Marines. Both sides have unique elements that separate them from the other faction. Each faction has their own commander. All of the players, aside from the commanders, are essentially playing a FPS. The commanders, however, are playing a RTS. The commander, as the name states, tells the other players what to do. The other players are not forced to do what the commander says, so this is a very team-oriented game. The commander also researches upgrades for the other players and can build structures. Being a commander requires a lot of knowledge about the game, so I wouldn't recommend being the commander until you have at least a general understanding of the game. The goal isn't to get as many kills in a certain period of time; instead, each side needs to destroy the other's base. Most games last 30-50 minutes, and there are no penalties for leaving early. Players can also join a game mid-way through. In my eyes, this is a pro since I don't always have the time to play an entire game. I feel like this game was exceptionally well done and offers a unique concept that keeps me coming back for more.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Kinda just my thoughts on the game right now. Gonna try to play it again, havent in probably half a year, but yeah...I love shooters and I love rts games. This game is basically the child of those 2 genres. I like shooters with strange or different movement styles and melee combat, which this game has, but I also like the occasional pew pew rifle or pellet gun.The marines - I think the gun play is great, even if at times you are just gunning down a rhino gorrilla. The meat shots on the shotguns, when you can hit them, feels amazing. Direct hits on smaller aliens with the grenade launcher also gives me an erection. The flamethrower, when you just don't want to aim. And then there are the mech suits, the hulking  pieces of armor that attract...too much attention, even if they can gun down tons of aliens, they can still be overrun. The aliens - I liked starcraft 2, and zerg was my favorite race. These are like them with some changes. Skulks climbing on walls and ceiling waiting to ambush the cautious marine, the gorge just supporting and being cute, the lerk being an annoying birb, the fade drive-bys, and the onos just coming in and killing anything in its path, that is if you stay in its path.This is one game I couldn't play for about 2 years due to the fact my old PC wasn't strong enough, and even when I first played when there wasn't much of a community left, it was still fun. It was probably harder to learn, since most people that still play have played longer than i have, and they are more likely at a higher skill level than I, but I still was able to learn slowly but surely. That is one thing, though, that may shy you away from trying it, but if you are willing to learn the game it will get fun.

												This was a game I was extremely excited about when TotalBiscuit review it with the game developers a few years ago.It was really fun too, for a while.But as time went by, a lot of veteran players started almost bullying new players.It's not a noob friendly game, is what I'm saying.Your teammates are way too bossy at times, nobody lets you do your own thing, do you own decisions.No you have to do what they want you to do."Don't hang around there. number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												One of the most fun and interesting multiplayer shooters. Oh, and its VERY arcade!The game has two competing sides that play vastly differently, which is something rarely seen in multiplayer games, especially shooters. Playing as aliens is nothing like playing marines. Moreover, commanding makes the game actually a Real Time Strategy with other players as your units! However,  each side is limited to one commander, so if you enjoy NS2 as RTS, then you might have a hard time playing it this way when there are other players who want to be a commander too. Nonetheless, there's a lot to enjoy in this game when played as FPP too. Not only because every unit (as aliens) and every different weapon (as humans) changes the style of the gameplay, but also because the game is quite intense and atmospheric (this is probably the best looking game I have ever seen too!). I highly recommend checking this game to everyone who like multiplayer action games, especially the arcade ones. The only drawbacks I can think of are infuriating loading times. I have never seen a game that would load maps even one third of a time as a NS2 maps load. This is quite annoying.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												+ Complex Strategy+ Marines and Aliens are well-balanced+ Variety of weapons/lifeforms gives the game a lot of replay value+ Commander Interface is easy to manouver; Alerts allow easy reactions to team requests+ Well-made Futuristic visuals for marines and Organic visuals for Aliens+ High-quality Audio+ Smooth animations + Good netcode+ Rookie-Friendly servers encourage a polite, respectable community- Very Long loading time for maps without a high-tier PC w/ SSD- Needs a more in-depth tutorial, especially for commander.- A vote or timed command to randomise a commander would help with the problem of having to wait for a commander for 5-10 minutes before the game starts, every game- Randomise Ready Room vote should allocate people evenly based on their skill levels, to help balance out teams- Force Even Teams vote does not make the teams even consistently- Glitch where dropping a medpack as commander will sometimes drop it on top of the map instead of in the room (I think this has been patched)9/10.

												This game is really different, and really interesting. Take tactical teamplay games like CS. Take futuristic RTS like Starcraft. Take a bit of MOBA games (I know, that does not sound good, but bare with me), a bit of FPS games, a bit of tactical games like Rainbow 6, and put them all together and shake. Yes, there is ALL that. And the thing is, it is done with great honesty, authenticity and seriousness. Developers did it with their heart, you can see it. Now ALL I wish, was that I had free time like when I was younger, that I had all my friends around me in LAN like when WE were younger, and to play for hours on that game. Because then it would be awesome. Without it, meh, it is just ok. But because of that potential that lucky people can exploit if they have time and friends, well, then I DO recommend that game to you, lucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												One word to describe NS2: unique. So what does it offer?- hybrid FPS/RTS (the only other game I know about that does the same is Nuclear Dawn, but ND has been abandonned    by its devs and is pretty much dead)- two completely different teams with different upgrades, tech trees, weapons, etc. encouraging different strategies- a lot of room for in-depth teamwork- each match is different, even on the same map = high replay value (btw maps are awesome)- unlike most RTS, NS2 allows for surprising comebacks (too many careless mistakes by players with high value classes/equipment can cripple the winning team very hard)- high skill ceiling (play with people of same skill or you'll be frustrated)- constant updatesMany of the old negative reviews do not apply anymore, as the game now puts you against people of same skill. I got this game when it was on sale for 5€, but to be honest even 10€ is a joke. Steam is full of♥♥♥♥♥♥games which are more expensive and don't even get close to the amount of content and replay value that NS2 offers.Don't get confused by the DLC, as I did. NS2 is not pay to win, everything is unlocked in the game. The DLCs are only skins, and most likely they will disappear soon anyways (one already did) due to the new NS2 item store. So expect more customization possibilites in the future. If you think about buying this: do it. There simply is no other game like this.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Game used to be extremely fun, but over time it got worse and is dead now. Developers pushed the eSports angle pretty hard with balancing, despite the competitive side of it never getting big. So the game was balanced for 6v6, despite most of the player base being in 24+ player servers. When rounds had teams that where evenly matched, the game was fantastic, your team could snatch victory from the jaws of defeat if played well. The only problem is that happened very little, most matches played where just one sided stomps or had one team voting to surrender within the first 5 minutes of the match. New players are treated poorly in servers and they wouldn't get any help or tips from other people.The developer forums were also a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ place in general where asking questions about balancing or game development decisions would be met with a passive aggressive "Thread locked :)" from moderators.

Posted: April 8, 2016
												I haven't played this for quite some time (A few years maybe?), there have been a number of updates I've not seen. So instead, I'll point to the overall mechanics of the game.Assymetrical gameplay is a very brave thing to attempt in a game, even some games that attempted it (e.g Planetside) later flattened the playing field substantially. Playing as an alien in NS2 is fun, traversing vent systems, clinging to ceilings and pouncing on marines is pretty immersive. It's quite interesting to see gameplay from the perspective of 'the alien menace,' when so many other games are about marines etc. hunting down aliens.Marines... I didn't enjoy them so much for personal reasons. If you wandered too far from your teammates you could be cut down very quickly by an even vaguely coordinated pack of skulks. Also quite immersive in that regard. This isn't really a balance issue, it's more about the ability to cooperate.Some of the issues I've read about in other reviews, such as uncooperative teammates, is unfortunately a common gripe with multiplayer. Unless you play together with a group of friends and use TS, someone is always going to ignore the commander and do what they like.When I played at the time the 'Rookie System' didn't seem to do very much. You could join a server that was 'rookie friendly' and still find players much more experienced than you playing there. At the same time,  no one wanted the responsibility of commanding, but were very good at back-seat commanding if you made a mistake.At the time, there was no tutorial. I imagine that's changed, or at least I would hope. There was a 'tutorial' where you could run around a map and had little hud markers explaining what cysts were, power cells and other upgrade structures, but it didn't really explain HOW to play the game. As a result, I feel a lot of people probably didn't pick up competency very quickly and became disenchanted with it.Lastly, there are a number of negative reviews which mention a toxic community. I haven't really had much experience of this myself, but this is going back years now. You should definitely heed those warnings, they seem fairly consistent. Many also reiterate that the game is dead.To summarise; the gameplay is enjoyable, immersive and an interesting step in game design that hopefully will be used as a reference for how to create assymetrical gameplay enjoyable, in the future. However, the community is apparently a small group full of toxicity, so put on your thick skin.I can only recommend this game to people who could convince maybe 20 people to play it with them occasionally. Otherwise, you will probably be disappointed.

number of helpful: 21 of 40 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												If you start Rocket League, your goal is simple: Get the ball in the other team's goal by bumping it with your car! Everything else is a small accessory to that goal.By comparison, just knowing the basics of Natural Selection 2 is a catacomb of logic. It makes you realize why games like TF2 and even Battlefield now focus on the idea of just having single-objective maps; diverting your focus between the five things going on at any time is often near-impossible. This is combined with very precise control requirements for each of the characters involved. For a marine, a skulk can jump across 30 degrees of your vision in less than half a second, and as any alien, having a constant arena awareness to make use of mobility is an immense challenge.This does two things. The high skill floor causes a massive divide between skill levels. For instance, a bad skulk will get 1 kill in an entire game, and a good skulk will be undefeatable even to basic enemy marines. Second, it causes any team failure to become heavily compounded. If you've played a TF2 game with just one team member AFK, you tend to notice it. In NS2, just having someone not doing 20 things a minute as a commander can screw everyone over.The pressure to perform well moment to moment has, sadly, turned the community pretty sour, much like a game like League of Legends. Even simple failings of the team like failing to act quickly in the face of overwhelming amounts of information (for instance, constant references to named map locations) can cause commanders to exasperate "Geez, we might as well forfeit, we have NO teamwork going on". Worse, if the team doesn't vote to concede, a completely lost match will drag on for half an hour with no map change. (Unlike a game like League of Legends, there's just no opportunities for comebacks - the entire resource system of the game encourages the "rolling wrecking ball" mentality)Perhaps this game would be fun with months of practice, played solely with players who have similar amounts of experience; but even if you can get that first goal you'd likely just become one of the aforementioned commanders.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												First Person Shooter crossed with an RTS. Marines Vs Aliens in a fight to take out the other's base. Each side is led by a commander who views the game in a Top-Down style RTS view. Their soldiers are controlled by other players in First-Person. Lots of weapons, upgrades, and equipment keep the game interesting depending on which order they are researched by the commander.Each team plays differently, but each also has an incredibly high learning curve. This game is not for the impatient or the lone-wolf. This is a team-based game. Players that don't work together will die, teams that are divided will lose. Coordination, communication, and tactics are far more valuable weapons than any Railgun or Onos.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												As a Half-Life fan, I heard of this mod long time ago - but never played it. I bought the new edition last year (mainly to support the developers) and was a bit scared by the fact that they built their own engine. After trying it out I was impressed by the visuals and gameplay, but unhappy with performance and mouse input. Because of that, the game did not draw my attention for too long.Lately, I gave NS2 a second chance and must admit that they put great effort into updates. You can use raw mouse input and the performance has increased dramatically. Furthermore the skill level is quite high (I think there is a competitive scene) and it is really fun to fool around as a total noob on public servers.The aiming skills needed are different (in comparision to e. g. Counter-Strike) because aliens are very fast, can be nearly everywhere and a lot of close combat situations arise. The RTS part of the game (commanding) seems to introduce a lot of cooperation and teamwork even to public servers.There are always full servers and the community is surprisingly friendly (voice communication is quite common). This is a great game, worth to buy even at full price - if you have time to play.

content:
Posted: February 8
												Re-writing a review to remind everyone how awesome this game is.To those who are going to buy it: no, it is not that kind of a shooter where you get the game basics in an hour after your first launch. No, this is not a game where you will be a all-killing badass as soon as you log in. This game has a very complicated mechanics, with a plenty of stuff to learn and even more stuff to master. Prepare your lips as you will suck a lot. After all those hours played I still die ten times more often than I kill.I love teamwork - this game is unplayable without it. Mosty I play because of the great teamwork.I love tactics - hide or charge that is the question.I love biting stuff - still can't do it properly, but it is fun!I love drama - get lost and hide in a corner hearing enemy steps somewhere aroundI love cute animals - gorges are gorgeous!I love green slmey stuff - you can spread it here!Some people complain that community is awful - it is but only on a newbie's servers. There are a lot of kids and russians. Get used to the game a little and jump to a non-rookie server.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2012
												Definately not a casual game, it requires some time to learn the mechanics. But when you do, it offers a one-of-a-kind experience due to having/being a human commander. The gameplay on the field is rather versatile as there is a variety of life forms and equipment to chose from. There is a great emphasis on teamplay, so I'd highly recommend playing with a headset. This is by far the game on steam I spent most time on, but for public purposes I have to give it only a 8/10 as it's not easily approachable and requires rather powerful hardware. Still absolutely recommending it, I have yet to find anything that is even remotely compareable in gameplay and feel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												NS2 one of those games where even after hundreds of hours, I feel like I still kind of suck at it - but darn it, I'm still having lots of fun!It is an excellent game - maybe simple in concept, but beautifully executed. The alien side is novel and fascinating, and challenges you to think outside the box with tactics. On the marine side, you feel a hint of horror genre as you attempt to wreak righteous vengeance on the aliens invading your space station. Crucially, this game gets almost every aspect of its game mechanics right, in places where most other FPS-RTS combo games fail. Matches are generally of a satisfying length,  progress and change over time, and have plenty of room for pulling victory out of the jaws (get it?) of defeat when you're on the losing side. Balance, while an issue in every RTS-FPS combo, is better than most in the genre. Asymmetry is utilized to great effect. Teamwork is encouraged by the game mechanics.I do find myself switching to the combat mod at times when I get frustrated by permanently losing high-level characters due to a small mistake - I don't know if the learning curve can be improved or the frustation can be dampened but for now it's just par for the course, and makes it all the more thrilling when you pull off death-defying feats.

content:
Posted: February 8
												Re-writing a review to remind everyone how awesome this game is.To those who are going to buy it: no, it is not that kind of a shooter where you get the game basics in an hour after your first launch. No, this is not a game where you will be a all-killing badass as soon as you log in. This game has a very complicated mechanics, with a plenty of stuff to learn and even more stuff to master. Prepare your lips as you will suck a lot. After all those hours played I still die ten times more often than I kill.I love teamwork - this game is unplayable without it. Mosty I play because of the great teamwork.I love tactics - hide or charge that is the question.I love biting stuff - still can't do it properly, but it is fun!I love drama - get lost and hide in a corner hearing enemy steps somewhere aroundI love cute animals - gorges are gorgeous!I love green slmey stuff - you can spread it here!Some people complain that community is awful - it is but only on a newbie's servers. There are a lot of kids and russians. Get used to the game a little and jump to a non-rookie server.
